block.p: INTERNATIONAL
The European Community may adopt a sweeping set of rules that would restrict the use of computerized information like personal medical and insurance records. [ Page A1. ]
Toyota will begin selling cars in Israel despite the continuing Arab economic boycott, Toyota officials say. [ D1. ]
INTERNATIONAL
The European Community may adopt a sweeping set of rules that would restrict the use of computerized information like personal medical and insurance records. [ Page A1. ]
Toyota will begin selling cars in Israel despite the continuing Arab economic boycott, Toyota officials say. [ D1. ]
In the controversy over the flow of technology to Iraq, the White House denied that an official had been dismissed. [ D2. ]
Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia have called on the European Community to remove some trade barriers. [ D2. ] COMPANIES

Revlon agreed to sell some of its main product lines, including Max Factor, to Procter & Gamble, thereby doubling Procter & Gamble's beauty business and raising money to pay off Revlon's heavy bank debt. [ D1. ] The acquisition set off a scramble for Max Factor's advertising account. [ D5. ]

Two bits of bad news for Chevron: A Federal judge ordered it to pay an estimated $180 million in additional pension benefits to more than 19,000 former employees of Gulf Oil. [ D1. ] And a California agency denied a Chevron request for temporary permission to transport oil by tanker from a field off the coast. [ D4. ]
I.B.M.'s super-lightweight notebook-size computers are available in Japan but not in the U.S. [ D1. ]
Nintendo has agreed to pay up to $25 million in rebates to buyers to settle allegations of price fixing. [ D1. ]
Boeing agreed to sell its de Havilland commuter aircraft division to Aeritalia of Italy and Aerospatiale of France. [ D4. ]
With Metropolitan Life moving 3,000 jobs out of New York, employees face tough decisions. [ B1. ] THE ECONOMY
The workers' compensation system of insurance is struggling to stay afloat in at least seven states. [ D1. ]
A program to develop better supercomputers will generate more than $10 billion in revenue, a study says. [ D5. ]
U.S. businesses plan to increase spending on plants and equipment by 3.2 percent this year, the Government said. [ D7. ]
The S.E.C. is looking into the possibility of illegal insider trading in the "junk bond" market. [ D16. ]
In the battle to slow health care spending, employers and the U.S. have virtually run out of ammunition, a study says. [ D19. ]
The Massachusetts plan to guarantee health insurance for all is faltering. [ A1. ]
The F.D.A. is overwhelmed and incapable of coping with vastly increased duties, a Federal advisory panel says. [ A1. ]
The U.S. should act promptly on global warming, with steps including raising auto mileage standards, a study says. [ B12. ]
A boycott of sports events sponsored by tobacco companies was urged by Health Secretary Louis W. Sullivan. [ B13. ] MARKETS
Stocks changed little, with Wall Street uncertain about how inflation figures will look. The Dow gained 1.48, to 2,874.50. [ D10. ]
Poor demand at an auction of seven-year Treasury notes pushed down prices of outstanding notes and bonds. [ D16. ]
Unleaded gasoline futures rose after a report showed a drop in gasoline stocks. [ D17. ] The dollar rose. [ D17. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS
The business of buying or merging companies went on almost as usual even as war loomed. Talking Deals. [ D2. ]
Backer Spielvogel Bates hired Donald Easdon, best known for the Infiniti campaign. Kim Foltz: Advertising. [ D8. ]
Meshulam Riklis is making an offer to McCrory bondholders that appears resistible. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D10. ]
